headline: Climate change: World's oceans suffer from record-breaking year of heat
context: Matt McGrath, Mark Poynting and Justin Rowlatt

annotations.paragraph: BBC News Climate & Science
annotations.reason: This is a section header and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Fuelled by climate change, the world's oceans have broken temperature records every single day over the past year, a BBC analysis finds.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a key fact about the record-breaking ocean temperatures linked to climate change.

annotations.paragraph: Nearly 50 days have smashed existing highs for the time of year by the largest margin in the satellite era.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers specific data about the frequency and magnitude of record-breaking temperatures.

annotations.paragraph: Planet-warming gases are mostly to blame, but the natural weather event El Niño has also helped warm the seas.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the causes of the ocean temperature increase, providing essential context.

annotations.paragraph: The super-heated oceans have hit marine life hard and driven a new wave of coral bleaching.
annotations.reason: This paragraph describes the impact of the ocean heat on marine life, which is directly relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: The analysis is based on data from the EU's Copernicus Climate Service.
annotations.reason: Provides the source of the data used in the analysis, which is relevant to the credibility of the findings.

annotations.paragraph: Copernicus also confirmed that last month was the warmest April on record in terms of global air temperatures, extending that sequence of month-specific records to 11 in a row.
annotations.reason: Offers additional context on global temperature trends, supporting the main premise of climate change impacts.

annotations.paragraph: For many decades, the world's oceans have been the Earth's 'get-out-of-jail card' when it comes to climate change.
annotations.reason: Provides context on the historical role of oceans in climate regulation, relevant to understanding their current state.

annotations.paragraph: Not only do they absorb around a quarter of the carbon dioxide that humans produce, they also soak up around 90% of the excess heat.
annotations.reason: Explains the critical function of oceans in mitigating climate change, directly related to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: But over the past year, the oceans have displayed the most concerning evidence yet that they are struggling to cope, with the sea surface particularly feeling the heat.
annotations.reason: Highlights the current challenges faced by oceans, directly supporting the article's main point about record-breaking heat.

annotations.paragraph: From March 2023, the average surface temperature of the global oceans started to shoot further and further above the long-term norm, hitting a new record high in August.
annotations.reason: Provides specific information about the timeline and record-breaking ocean temperatures.

annotations.paragraph: Recent months have brought no respite, with the sea surface reaching a new global average daily high of 21.09C in February and March this year, according to Copernicus data.
annotations.reason: Offers updated data on ocean temperatures, reinforcing the record-breaking trend.

annotations.paragraph: As the graph below shows, not only has every single day since 4 May 2023 broken the daily record for the time of year, but on some days the margin has been huge.
annotations.reason: Highlights the unprecedented nature of the temperature records being broken daily.

annotations.paragraph: Around 47 days smashed the record for that day of the year by at least 0.3C, according to BBC analysis of Copernicus data.
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on the frequency and magnitude of record-breaking days.

annotations.paragraph: Never before in the satellite era had the margin of record been this big.
annotations.reason: Emphasizes the historical significance of the current temperature records.

annotations.paragraph: These key ocean nurseries turn white and die because the waters they live in grow too hot. They are a critical element in the ocean ecosystem, home to around a quarter of all marine species.
annotations.reason: Provides context on the impact of ocean heat on marine ecosystems.

annotations.paragraph: AFP
annotations.reason: This is an image credit and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Unusually warm seas may also have taken a direct toll on one of the most beloved ocean-going creatures in the coldest continent, the emperor penguin.
annotations.reason: Introduces the impact of ocean heat on emperor penguins, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: "There have been examples of the sea-ice collapsing before emperor chicks have properly fledged, and there have been mass drowning events," says Prof Meredith.
annotations.reason: Provides specific examples and expert commentary on the impact of ocean heat on emperor penguins.

annotations.paragraph: "The emperor penguin is a threatened species because of climate change, and the sea-ice and the ocean temperatures are strongly implicated in that."
annotations.reason: Directly links climate change and ocean temperatures to the threat faced by emperor penguins.

annotations.paragraph: Species that are more invasive appear to be responding more strongly to global warming and the increasing water temperatures, Prof Barber says.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides information on how invasive species are reacting to climate change, which is relevant to the impact of ocean heat.

annotations.paragraph: One important factor that's made the last year more impactful in seas all over the world has been the El Niño weather phenomenon, adding to human-driven emissions of warming gases.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains a key factor contributing to the record-breaking ocean heat, directly related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: El Niño sees warmer waters come to the surface of the Pacific. As a result, it tends to push up the global average.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides context on how El Niño affects global temperatures, relevant to the article's focus on ocean heat.

annotations.paragraph: But other ocean basins that aren't usually affected by El Niño have also experienced record marine heatwaves - leaving scientists trying to work out exactly what is going on.
annotations.reason: This paragraph highlights unusual patterns in ocean heat, contributing to the narrative of record-breaking temperatures.

annotations.paragraph: "The Atlantic has been warmer than usual, and this is not a pattern you normally associate with El Niño - so it's something somehow different," explains Carlo Buontempo, director of Copernicus.
annotations.reason: The quote provides expert insight into unusual warming patterns in the Atlantic, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: This heat is still persisting in many ocean basins, including the tropical Atlantic.
annotations.reason: Provides specific information about the persistence of heat in ocean basins.

annotations.paragraph: "There is still a large patch of warmer than usual water in the tropical Atlantic [and] this is the main development region for tropical cyclones," explains Dr Buontempo.
annotations.reason: Offers expert commentary on the impact of warmer waters in a key region.

annotations.paragraph: "We are almost a month ahead in the sea surface temperature in the Atlantic with respect to the annual cycle [...] so this is an area that has to be watched."
annotations.reason: Highlights the unusual timing of temperature changes and the need for monitoring.

annotations.paragraph: As well as these short-term impacts, researchers warn there will be long-term consequences that society will have to adapt to.
annotations.reason: Introduces the concept of long-term consequences of ocean heat.

annotations.paragraph: For example, ice-sheet melting and deep-ocean warming are likely to continue to fuel sea-level rise in the centuries to come.
annotations.reason: Provides specific examples of long-term impacts related to ocean heat.

annotations.paragraph: "When we talk about climate change, we tend to reduce that to changes on the surface because we live there," said Angélique Melet, a researcher with Mercator Ocean International.
annotations.reason: The quote provides insight into common perceptions of climate change, relevant to the topic.

annotations.paragraph: "However, the deep ocean is one of the aspects [of global warming] that is committing us to centuries and millennia of [climate] change."
annotations.reason: This quote highlights the long-term impact of climate change on the deep ocean, relevant to the topic.

annotations.paragraph: But Dr Melet stresses that is not a reason to give up on cutting emissions.
annotations.reason: This statement emphasizes the importance of continued efforts to reduce emissions, relevant to the topic.

annotations.paragraph: "Depending on our actions, we can reduce the speed of that warming, and we can decrease the overall amplitude of that warming and sea-level rise."
annotations.reason: The quote discusses potential actions to mitigate climate change effects, relevant to the topic.
